article.headline: This video of a tearful Georgia police officer accusing McDonaldâs of withholding her Egg McMuffin order on purpose has gone viral
article.body: Thereâs not much sympathy online for this cop crying over an Egg McMuffin. A video of a tearful Georgia police officer accusing McDonaldâs MCD, -0.43% Â workers of withholding her breakfast order went viral on Twitter TWTR, -0.23% Â on Wednesday, leading the local franchisee to apologize to the officer and clarify to MarketWatch that she âwas never denied service.â A Twitter user who called herself âAnnâ and identified as a conservative Trump supporter in her profile, which has since been taken down, posted the clip of a woman that has been identified as Stacy Talbert, who sobs while recounting how the restaurant workers kept her waiting and withheld part of her breakfast order. Talbert suggests this was done on purpose as part of the growing backlash against officers and the calls for police reform in the weeks since Breonna Taylor, George Floyd and Rayshard Brooks were killed during their encounters with law enforcement. âStacey [sic] who has been a cop for 15 yrs went to @McDonalds,â Ann writes in her post, which has since been taken down. âShe paid for it in advance and this is how she gets treated for being a cop.â MarketWatch reached out to Ann, but she did not respond by press time. But the local McDonaldâs owner/operators confirmed the incident to MarketWatch, and Talbert later verified the video to NBC News. Annâs post was viewed at least 13.4 million times and retweeted tens of thousands of times by Wednesday evening; itâs not clear when the post or the account was taken down. But it renewed a heated online debate about the relationship between police officers and the communities they serve. Talbert, a sheriffâs deputy in McIntosh County, Ga., told NBC that she recorded herself on Facebook Live FB, +0.26% Â on Monday morning after finishing an overnight shift. The clip, which is just under 2Â½ minutes, features her explaining that she placed a mobile order for an Egg McMuffin meal. But her order wasnât ready when she went to pick it up. âAnd Iâm waiting. And Iâm waiting. And Iâm waiting,â she says, noting that she was hungry because she had not eaten for a very long time. She was told to pull over to the side, and an employee eventually came over and gave her a coffee. But Talbertâs order was supposed to include an Egg McMuffin and a hash brown, as well. âThatâs all she hands me is the coffee,â she says, breaking down into tears. âI said, âDonât bother with the food because right now Iâm too nervous to take it!â It doesnât matter how many hours Iâve been up. It doesnât matter what Iâve done for anyone. Right now, Iâm too nervous to take a meal from McDonaldâs because I canât see it being made!â She pleaded with people watching the video to, âPlease, just give us a break. I donât know how much more I can take.â She added that she has never had such anxiety in all of her years of service, and asked people to say âthank youâ when they see cops. Related:The police officer crying in that viral Egg McMuffin video wants you to know sheâs âsick of people being meanâ The original poster, Ann, also shared the phone number of that particular McDonaldâs restaurant at the Loveâs Travel Stop in Richmond Hill, Ga. âCome on America. We are better than this,â she wrote. But many of the tens of thousands of comments beneath the video have taken a less supportive tone. In fact, some viewers claimed they were going to call the restaurant to demand raises for the workers who had to âdeal with Officer Karenâ instead. Some pointed out that Talbert had no idea what was going on inside the kitchen or restaurant while her order was being prepared. âShe thinks fast food workers have time to delay her order intentionally as if they arenât constantly being micromanaged, or that they can even keep track of who had a single egg McMuffin,â wrote one. AnotherÂ wrote,Â âMy first job was at McDonaldâs. The drink always comes out first. Breakfast sandwiches are made in batches, unless you asked for something special the person in the back is just making batches of them. Hashbrowns are fried in the deep fryer & batches have to be made.â Local McDonaldâs operator/owners Gary and Jill Stanberry told MarketWatch in an emailed statement that they have been in contact with Talbert to apologize. âUnfortunately, we were made aware of a local police officer who experienced a longer than usual wait time and did not receive her full order right away at one of our restaurants. We have been in contact with this officer to apologize for this unsatisfactory experience and let her know that we would love to correct the inaccurate order when she has time. We are happy to report that the officer was never denied service and also shared positive feedback on the employee with whom she interacted,â the owners told MarketWatch. âOur priority is for all customers to feel welcome and enjoy a great customer experience in our family-owned restaurants, including local law enforcement officers who protect and serve our community,â they added.Â Â âAs a locally owned and operated business, we work hard every day to treat all of our employees and customers with dignity and respect.â Other commentators highlighted the systemic injustices against people of color that have been highlighted and protested with renewed vigor in recent weeks. âImagine the worst oppression youâve ever felt is McDonaldâs making you wait 10 minutes for a McMuffin,â wrote a user under the name Sarina. iframe.twitter-tweet { width: 100% !important; } iframe.twitter-tweet { width: 100% !important; } Other critics questioned Talbertâs ability to serve as an officer if she is this upset about her food being delayed. iframe.twitter-tweet { width: 100% !important; } iframe.twitter-tweet { width: 100% !important; } Talbert countered those complaints in an interview with BuzzFeed News. âIt was exactly how every single officer feels,â she said, âand if they donât feel compassion or emotion, if they donât cry over anything, I promise you that is not the officer that you want on the street.â Still others just made fun of the clip, which led to terms such as âOfficer Karenâ and âMcMuffinâ trending on Twitter on Wednesday morning. âKarenâ has become a slang term for the stereotype of an entitled, privilege white woman. Talbert responded to these remarks by telling NBC sheâs laughed at some of the jokes. âItâs actually kind of funny,â she said. But she noted that the original intent of her post has been lost. âIâm just so sick of people being mean ... I just wanted to share that I hurt, too.â There were also Twitter users expressing love and support for law enforcement officers with hashtags like #BackTheBlue and #DefendThePolice, or floating the idea of a boycott against McDonaldâs. âCops are losing their confidence with so much hate around. Sheâs exhausted and fear has crept in,â wrote one user under the name Jill Gooding. âWe are in a very sad state of affairs.â This video went viral just days after two New York Police Department Unions accused Manhattan Shake Shack SHAK, +1.82% Â employees of poisoning officers by mixing bleach into their milkshakes. But the NYPDâs Chief of Detectives Rodney Harrison laterÂ tweetedÂ that there was âno criminalityâ involved, and in fact, the officers were inadvertently sickened as a result of the âfaulty cleaningâ of a machine. This article was originally published on June 17, and has been updated with the officerâs identity and her comments. It also notes that the original Twitter post that went viral has been taken down, as has that account.
